verses.text: Then Jesus told them a parable about always needing to pray and not lose heart.
verses.comment: Jesus stresses the persistence of prayer, not as vain repetition but true perseverance. The call to continual prayer echoes the broader biblical command to 'pray without ceasing' (1 Thess. 5:17). This highlights the need for a sustained, disciplined prayer life that shapes the soul.

verses.text: He said, 'There was a judge in a certain city who did not fear God nor respect people.'
verses.comment: Jesus introduces an unjust judge to contrast human indifference with God's justice, showing even flawed human authority cannot block the value of persistent prayer.

verses.text: And there was a widow in that city, who kept coming to him, saying, 'Give me justice against my adversary.'
verses.comment: The widow, representing social vulnerability, demonstrates the power of humble persistence—God's ear is especially attentive to the lowly and oppressed (see Ps. 146:9).

verses.text: For a while he refused, but afterward he said to himself, 'Even though I do not fear God or respect people,'
verses.comment: The judge acts from selfish motives, not from reverence for God or duty to others. This heightens the contrast between God and even fallen human authorities.

verses.text: 'Yet because this widow keeps bothering me, I will give her justice, so that she will not wear me out by her continual coming.'
verses.comment: The widow’s steadfastness overcomes the judge’s reluctance. If persistence yields results even with unjust men, how much more will God answer persistent prayer.

verses.text: And the Lord said, 'Hear what the unrighteous judge says.'
verses.comment: Jesus draws attention to the lesson: If unjust authority responds to persistence, the message is clear about God’s greater generosity.

verses.text: And will not God give justice to his chosen ones, who cry out to him day and night? Will he delay long over them?
verses.comment: God’s goodness surpasses all human standards; those set apart to belong to Him (the 'chosen') have the assurance that persevering prayer is heard.

verses.text: I tell you, he will give them justice quickly. Nevertheless, when the Son of Man comes, will he find faith on the earth?'
verses.comment: Jesus uses 'Son of Man' as a Messianic and divine claim referencing Daniel 7:13. The question challenges believers to practice enduring faith, especially before His return.

verses.text: He also told this parable to some who trusted in themselves that they were righteous, and looked down on others:
verses.comment: Self-righteousness is identified as the danger; reliance on personal merit leads to spiritual blindness.

verses.text: 'Two men went up to the temple to pray, one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector.'
verses.comment: The Pharisee and the tax collector represent opposite ends of the social and spiritual spectrum. The temple context emphasizes the importance of sacred space for prayer.

verses.text: The Pharisee stood by himself and prayed, 'God, I thank you that I am not like other men—extortioners, unjust, adulterers, or even like this tax collector.'
verses.comment: The Pharisee’s posture is prideful, reflecting a distorted view of holiness—he measures righteousness by comparison, rather than dependence on God’s mercy.

verses.text: 'I fast twice a week; I give tithes of all that I get.'
verses.comment: He relies on external works—fasting and tithing—as the basis for his justification, missing the necessity of interior conversion.

verses.text: But the tax collector, standing far off, would not even lift his eyes to heaven, but beat his chest, saying, 'God, be merciful to me, a sinner!'
verses.comment: The tax collector embodies true contrition—his prayer directly parallels Psalm 51. This act demonstrates the posture God desires: humility, repentance, and trust in divine mercy, an essential framework for approaching God in worship.

verses.text: 'I tell you, this man went down to his house justified, rather than the other; for everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, and the one who humbles himself will be exalted.'
verses.comment: Justification before God depends on humility and repentance, not outward accomplishments. The language hints at a transformative encounter within a sacred setting.

verses.text: Now they were bringing even infants to him so that he might touch them. But when the disciples saw this, they rebuked them.
verses.comment: The reference to infants affirms their value before God and justification not being tied merely to understanding but to a state of receptivity. This verse also undergirds the practice of blessing children.

verses.text: But Jesus called them to him, saying, 'Let the little children come to me, and do not hinder them, for to such belongs the kingdom of God.'
verses.comment: Christ emphasizes the inclusive nature of God’s kingdom and welcomes even the most vulnerable. The passage supports both the dignity of children and their inclusion in the worshiping community.

verses.text: Truly, I say to you, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God like a little child will never enter it.
verses.comment: Jesus’s teaching underscores the necessity of childlike trust and surrender for salvation. Notice the emphasis on 'receiving,' not merely intellectual assent, resonating with the biblical call to become as little children in faith and humility.

verses.text: A certain ruler asked him, 'Good Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?'
verses.comment: The ruler recognizes Jesus’ authority as a 'Good Teacher' and seeks the way of eternal life. His question reveals a longing for assurance through moral action.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'Why do you call me good? No one is good except God alone.'
verses.comment: Jesus prompts the ruler to recognize the source of true goodness—God Himself—and to reflect deeply on whom Jesus truly is. Many scholars see here an implicit claim to divinity, for Jesus does not disown the title 'good.'

verses.text: 'You know the commandments: You shall not commit adultery, You shall not murder, You shall not steal, You shall not bear false witness, Honor your father and mother.'
verses.comment: Jesus lists the basic requirements of the moral law, summarizing the commandments relating to others, and showing the enduring value of God’s commandments in Christian life.

verses.text: He replied, 'All these I have kept since I was a youth.'
verses.comment: The ruler’s claim echoes Paul’s sense of blamelessness under the law—revealing the limitations of mere external observance.

verses.text: When Jesus heard this, he said to him, 'You still lack one thing. Sell all that you have, distribute to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; then come, follow me.'
verses.comment: Jesus calls for radical detachment from worldly possessions and absolute trust in Him. The invitation, 'follow me,' is a call to discipleship that includes sacrificial love and even the renunciation of earthly goods, a counsel embraced by those who seek perfection and deeper union with Christ.

verses.text: But when he heard these things, he became very sad, for he was extremely rich.
verses.comment: Attachment to wealth remains a formidable obstacle to wholehearted discipleship—the cost of following Jesus is a recurring call to radical conversion.

verses.text: Jesus, seeing that he had become very sad, said, 'How hard it is for those who have riches to enter the kingdom of God!'
verses.comment: Earthly riches can blind one to spiritual poverty and the need for grace, placing trust in worldly security above the call of the Gospel.

verses.text: Indeed, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God.'
verses.comment: The imagery intensifies the warning—salvation is a miracle of grace, not a product of human effort or wealth.

verses.text: Those who heard it said, 'Then who can be saved?'
verses.comment: The disciples recognize the radical nature of Jesus’ teaching. Salvation is beyond human capability apart from God’s initiative.

verses.text: But he said, 'What is impossible with men is possible with God.'
verses.comment: Salvation is ultimately a gift from God—a work of divine grace that overcomes our weakness.

verses.text: Peter said, 'See, we have left our own things and followed you.'
verses.comment: Peter expresses the disciple’s willingness to forsake worldly security. The act of leaving all to follow Christ prefigures a radical discipleship embodied and continued in the apostolic tradition.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Truly, I say to you, there is no one who has left house or wife or brothers or parents or children, for the sake of the kingdom of God,
verses.comment: Jesus acknowledges the cost of discipleship, even family sacrifice, for the sake of the kingdom. This hints at the special vocation of those called to radically consecrate their lives to God.

verses.text: who will not receive many times more in this time, and in the age to come, eternal life.'
verses.comment: God promises

verses.text: Taking the twelve aside, he said to them, 'See, we are going up to Jerusalem, and everything written by the prophets about the Son of Man will be accomplished.'
verses.comment: Jesus predicts his Passion, fulfilling Old Testament prophecy (see Isa. 53; Ps. 22). The title 'Son of Man' once again declares his Mediator role and hidden divinity (Dan. 7:13).

verses.text: For he will be handed over to the Gentiles, and will be mocked, insulted, and spit upon.
verses.comment: Accurate prophecy of Christ’s suffering for our redemption. The events echo Isaiah’s Servant Songs and messianic psalms.

verses.text: They will scourge him and kill him, and on the third day he will rise again.'
verses.comment: The resurrection on 'the third day' fulfills prophetic patterns (Hos. 6:2) and establishes the core of the Christian faith. Jesus predicts both death and resurrection, claiming divine authority over life and death.

verses.text: But they understood none of these things; this saying was hidden from them, and they did not grasp what was said.
verses.comment: Spiritual truths are often veiled until God gives understanding. The inability of the disciples to comprehend foreshadows their later enlightenment after the resurrection.

verses.text: As he approached Jericho, a blind man was sitting by the road, begging.
verses.comment: The healing of the blind man testifies to Jesus’ power and fulfillment of messianic prophecies (e.g., Isa. 35:5). Blindness often symbolizes spiritual as well as physical need.

verses.text: Hearing a crowd going by, he asked what this meant.
verses.comment: The blind man’s inquiry opens the way for faith to act.

verses.text: They told him, 'Jesus of Nazareth is passing by.'
verses.comment: The title 'Jesus of Nazareth' identifies the humanity of Christ, yet the blind man will soon see his true identity.

verses.text: He called out, 'Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!'
verses.comment: By calling Jesus 'Son of David,' the blind man acclaims his messianic and royal identity—an act of profound faith. The plea for mercy is foundational to Christian prayer and worship.

verses.text: Those who were in front rebuked him, telling him to be quiet, but he cried out all the more, 'Son of David, have mercy on me!'
verses.comment: The persistence of the blind man in seeking mercy echoes themes of persevering prayer. The crowd's resistance mirrors the challenge of seeking Jesus amid discouragement.

verses.text: Jesus stopped and ordered that he be brought to him. When he came near, Jesus asked him,
verses.comment: Jesus's willingness to stop for the marginalized reflects God’s heart for the poor and humble. This mirrors the role of mediation—others bring the blind man to Jesus.

verses.text: 'What do you want me to do for you?' He said, 'Lord, let me recover my sight.'
verses.comment: The address 'Lord' affirms faith in Jesus’s divine authority. The restoration of sight is both physical and spiritual—true discipleship brings enlightenment.

verses.text: And Jesus said to him, 'Recover your sight; your faith has saved you.'
verses.comment: Faith is a channel of salvation and healing. The word 'saved' (Gk. 'sozo') encompasses both physical and spiritual restoration, demonstrating the wholeness brought by Christ.

verses.text: Immediately he recovered his sight and followed him, glorifying God. And all the people, when they saw it, gave praise to God.
verses.comment: The man’s instant response is discipleship and worship—following Jesus and glorifying God publicly. The miracle points to both Jesus’s divinity and the call to bear witness by lives of praise and faithful following.
